reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Feature packed phone at an economic price
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2025
reviews.body: Excellent phone for the price. I am mainly a Google Pixel user. However, I got this phone for my parent who mainly uses it for making phone calls. The call quality is on par with my Google Pixel phones. The phone packs useful features at an affordable price.  The phone has fingerprint sensor, face unlock in addition to basic pattern and pin unlock.The phone screen is large and pleasant to look at but not unwieldy.The bloat apps are minimal. Fortunately, Samsung allows you to uninstall majority of the apps this phone ships with. Therefore, I've uninstalled many of the unnecessary OEM apps. Before buying the phone, I went through a few reviews commenting on how laggy this phone is. However, I have not had any such lag issues.Buttons have reasonable tactile feel.It's plastic body feels fragile; however, it's functional. Fortunately, a $15 phone case addresses that problem.

reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Samsung Galaxy A16 Phone
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2025
reviews.body: I had a Moto phone, but the cracked screen (I guess I don't juggle phones very well) was interfering in being able to use it.  I had the screen replaced three times, and the phone still wouldn't work right, so I decided to move on.  I'm an Android user, and NOT techie at all, so I needed to stick with that system.  My son recommended this phone to me, and so far, I really like it.  It's easy to use, it feels good in my hand (size, shape, weight), and while the layout and some apps are different, I'm not having to relearn the entire phone.  The ONLY negative so far is using the 'swipe' texting feature.  My Moto gave me reasonable options.  This one comes up with words I'm not even sure ARE words, and they certainly don't make any sense in context.  Good phone, reasonable price.  Camera gives nice photos.

reviews.title:
4.0 out of 5 stars

reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2025

reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    TOP NOTCH!
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2025
reviews.body: I had a 2022 Motorola G Stylus 5G and it sucked! That Motorola was the worst phone I have ever owned. It was horribly slow and you couldn't open 2 apps at once. Then I bought this beautiful Samsung A16 5G at a really cheap price and I have to say, it's the best Samsung phone I have ever owned for the price. The quality and speed is definitely TOP NOTCH! You can open multiple apps and run with ease. It also has really good battery life too. It's all around a great phone and for the price it's your best option. Spend less and get a lot more.

reviews.title:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Typical Samsung Phone
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2025

They take up ram, rom, data, and battery. So ial media junk apps and games are first to go. Samsung keyboard also stinks, so plan on replacing it with Google's.Set up before you connect with home wifi, and before you jnstall sim card.Go to Apps and show sustem apps to unistall or disable meta , samsung, and even some google junk.then, you have a phone that can run snappy and get decent performance. The phrase " keep it simple" has it right. Too bad the people at Samsung are so Apple obsessed that they also lard up the phone with junk apps.

reviews.title:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    What do you want a phone for?
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2025
reviews.body: I love me some gadgets! I loved my Note 9. Well... not really. I don't like having something that constantly wants my attention. My kids are grown so leave me alone.There are a couple of apps I need to monitor. Short backstory: I am a real boomer. I was born in the first half of the last century. I remember party lines, rotary dials, and 7 digit phone numbers. Yes, thats before area codes.What I like about the A16.It didn't cost me my first born child... I mean it didn't cost me a months rent or small payments well into the afterlife.Its not ancient. I can make calls. I can read my health levels passively, although I'm still not getting my blood pressure cuff to talk to the phone...What I dont like about the A16The MOST annoying thing is it won't allow me to add different ringtones to different contactss. It was annoying enough that the Note 9 didn't allow me to change my notification sounds individually, when I could previously. I was allowed to copy contacts with different alert sounds with the Note 9. I can't with this phone. I know... first world problems. (rant off)This phone seems like it doesn't know if it is large phone or a small tablet. Neither do I.I am mad at myself for not noticing it doesn't hava a battery that will charge remotely. This boomer's hands don't work like they did when I was 30. I have trouble with plugging the thing to a charger.I am mostly annoyed that since I bought the phone from Amazon I had to do all the assembly myself, i.e. putting sim/sd cards in and transfering data. --also my fault. I think I have it 3 stars and not 4 because my devices hate me. All of them.

The whistles and bells make sense to me and am making a good attempt at using them.  At almost 60 years old I think its time to use it for all of its conveniences.  This one is user friendly.  My old phone (Samsung too), I felt I stumbled upon its amenities.  Where this one is dummie proof.

reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    great phone
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2025
reviews.body: I bought this to replace my Motorola phone which I was starting to hate, since it's resources are maxed out and even worse, won't maintain a network connection.  I like Samsung phones much better anyway, so when I saw the positive reviews on C-Net combined with the fact it works with Mint Mobile service, it was a no brainer.  Set up was a little longer than I expected, probably due to the fact my old Motorola phone kept dropping the internet.  I simply transferred my existing sim  and memory cards to the new phone and used the Smart Switch app to complete the switch.  In less than an hour, I received a text confirmation from Mint Mobile that the transfer was complete.  Keep in mind this does not come with a charger.  Very pleased overall.

reviews.title:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    A brand name phone without much to impress with
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2025
reviews.body: This is one of the least expensive Galaxy smartphones you can get in 2025, so for that I give credit where it's due.If you're comparing with other, more expensive Samsung devices, you may be disappointed at a lack of speed and features.If you're comparing with other off-brand phones at similar prices, there are pros and cons: lower specs on one hand; but more stable and reliable against weird bugs; and probably much easier to find various cases for what I'm sure will be a popular phone option this year.Where it stands out against other phones in the $200 price range is that it has the most popular "optional" features, 5G connectivity and NFC (tap-to-pay, etc).And, not surprising for a Samsung device but worth noting, I found the camera quality to be pretty good. Not *as* vivid as top tier Pixel, Galaxy, and iPhones of the past 2-3 years, but much much better than off-brand phones in this price range, of which I have tried several. Both the photo and video cameras look "good" - like, you wouldn't think your photos come out grainy or blurry or the camera can't focus. Unfortunately that's prevalent with other budget phones but Samsung has maintained a minimum level of quality with the camera.That's about where any "outstanding-ness" ends. The rest is an unremarkable, decent phone for everyday use. There is no "unboxing experience" - it comes in a very simple basic package – which is fine, pass the savings down to the consumer.  The screen is just a little bit larger than average, and has a vivid and clear display. Part of the phone's body is plastic, which also feels un-premium compared to other devices. The phone's internal specs, especially the 4GB RAM are pretty low for today's apps, even without trying to play 3D games or use AR filters and experiences. I found this phone occasionally lagging just to switch between apps like email and my browser, if I've been multitasking for a while.Battery life is OK and a fresh phone lasts comfortably throughout the day. It is compatible with 25w fast chargers but not wireless charging; disqualifying some accessories. You can get a full charge in under 2 hours.Finally, if you're curious about some of the Galaxy AI features that you may have seen on commercials... at the time of this review, most of them are not natively available to this phone. I mean, sure, you can download apps like Gemini, but the "circle it" and other features that are just directly part of the UI in higher-tier Samsung phones, are not available on this one.

reviews.title:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great Entry Level Phone
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2025
reviews.body: This is a great phone, all things considered, especially given its class as a lower end economy smartphone. Even though it's definitely value oriented, you get a pretty decent phone that can do quite a lot for you.First of all, the specs are mostly decent. You've got a large, bright display. You've got "decent" cameras. You're also getting a chipset that isn't too bad at all. Impressively, you're also getting 128GB of onboard storage. The one thing I think is unfortunate is the 4GB of RAM, which definitely doesn't feel like enough in this day and age. But that's just part of the tradeoff, I suppose.It's not fast, but it's not nearly as sluggish as I would have expected. Once it's settled down, it's a perfectly usable device without much frustration. The current Samsung software that runs on top of Android is actually a lot less bloated and "in your face" than it was a few years ago. Samsung has clearly taken some of that criticism seriously and created a slightly faster, less bloated, sleeker experience. Still, it's annoying to have to deal with having two different accounts just to get started (Samsung and Google), because there are two different "app stores," and Samsung insists you also use theirs to update their own apps. Remember that 4GB of RAM? Sometimes, if you're using a bunch of apps, there's a tendency for them to start closing due to trying to manage the RAM. It's definitely unfortunate.Build quality is another area where there are some "tradeoffs." It's an all plastic device aside from the screen. The sides are plastic, and the back is plastic. But it still looks and feels pretty good in the hand, and it's lightweight due to all that plastic as well. The speakers sound "OK" and get loud enough to use. Photo quality is noticeably unimpressive compared to flagship phones (which I tested it next to) but perfectly acceptable for general use.Overall, I would say that it's a solid device for its category, and I would recommend it.

reviews.title:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Decent Phone
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2025
reviews.body: Decent phone for the price point. Given that it is a new model it functioned very well. Although just a tad bit slower/laggy than I'm use compared to my old Galaxy S8+ but it's bearable. I don't run a lot of apps on it so you would think over the years that issue with the A series would be fixed. It was an easy transition to migrate my old Samsung data over so that was a plus. Visuals and screen clarity was nice. I like that it still had an expandable memory card slot for the phone. I also had no issues moving it to my carrier as it recognized it right away.

reviews.title:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great Phone!
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2025
reviews.body: The Samsung Galaxy A16 is a powerhouse.  We had no problem switching our old galaxy A10 phone with consumer cellular to this A16.  It was a smooth transaction.  I also downloaded the transfer app on the old Samsung with help of the new phone and was able to move my photos and other things like apps to the new phone.  It is fast and the screen large and clear.  The camera has great settings to take even professional looking photos.  I love that you can make the font large for elderly folks.  I wish the sound was louder on speaker though for folks that are hard of hearing.  I really wish Samsung would make their phones wireless as they are behind the times with that.  This phone was taking the place of our old Samsung so I just used the wireless adaptor we had which works fine.  Overall this is a very nice phone and  for a price under $200 compared to competitors which can be 5 times the price or more  you really cannot beat it.  I totally recommend this phone.

reviews.title:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Good battery life
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2025
reviews.body: Overall a decent phone that offers a high quality screen bright and vibrant . Good speaker quality for call and speaker phone clear and crisp . Fsat charged in about 1 hr or so . The ram is suffient enough for web surfing , shoping and average use . Nice build quality and all day battery life with moderate use . Camera quality is average the is fine for that average everyday user . Very functional and capable phone for daily use . Nice design good button response and value

reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great device, ESPECIALLY for the price
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2025
reviews.body: Had an extra line on our account and decided to get an inexpensive phone to attach it to. Been an iPhone user for many years now after previously being a long-time android user, and was excited to see how Android and Samsung had changed over the years. Short version - I was pleasantly surprised by this phone.PHYSICALFirst off, this is a big phone. A BIG phone! I've used a "Pro" size iPhone for the past 5 years, so the extra 1" in height and .25" in width took some getting used to. A nice thing about the phone being so large is that the screen is also very large, and my eyes definitely appreciated the extra size and clarity! Speaking of the screen, it's the typical gorgeous AMOLED screen that you expect from Samsung. You simply can't beat the contrast on a screen like that! The build quality seems very good, and it has a fingerprint reader built into the power button. A lot of great features and quality that I would expect from a much more expensive phone.CAMERAI'm very impressed by the camera setup. First off it has a 3 camera setup just like my iPhone 14 Pro, with the same Standard, Wide Angle and Zoom lens grouping. The primary camera is a 50mp sensor, which results in very sharp images that you can print out at very large sizes. It also has an option to take 12mp photos as well to save on storage space. That's more than enough resolution for social media posting and other digital uses. In my testing, photo quality has been great. The portrait mode on this phone I think is a better implementation than the portrait mode on my iPhone. The manual exposure controls were easy to access and use. Once again, quality I would expect from a $900+ phone.SOFTWAREStandard Samsung version of Android OS. You either love it or hate it. It came with a LOT of preinstalled apps which I really don't like, but that's not unique to this particular model of phone.HARDWAREThe processor/ram is really the only place where I felt this seemed like a "budget" phone. The system seemed a bit sluggish at times, with delayed response when calling up apps, menus or hitting the home button. Built in storage is pretty good at 128GB, but the ability to use a SD card to expand storage is awesome, and something you don't see too often (NEVER on an Apple product).PHONEWorks great as a phone; obviously speeds, connectivity and the like will be dependent on your network and location.OVERALLIn the short-term, this phone shows an incredible value with what you get for the price. If I'm spending $199 on a phone I typically expect to get something very basic and very plastic, with outdated features that are already on their last legs. This phone feels like it could hold it's own for quite a few years, and with a promise from Samsung of 6 OS updates in the future, it very likely will. Samsung hit a home run with this one!

reviews.title:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Does not have wireless charging
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2025
reviews.body: I understand that this is the budget line of phones from Samsung. I was still surprised to see that it has no wireless charging capability. Unfortunately, no one in my family wants to swap out their phone and lose that feature. I cant really review it beyond that. I will probably just turn it into a dedicated music player to par with some Bluetooth speakers.

reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Quality phone with a good screen.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2025
reviews.body: Its got a very nice screen that's easy to see, even in daylight.  It might be easier to see (in bright daylight) than my iPhone13. My wife has some games she likes to play on it, nothing incredibly taxing, but it has snappy performance, both loading the game in in the game, so memory is pretty quick as well as the GPU. The camera does a really good job as well, but phone cameras are all amazing these days, at least for the last 5-7 years.It's a really nice phone, but Samsung rarely disappoints and seems to stand behind their products with updates.

reviews.title:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Good Overall Phone, With the Added Peace of Mind from Samsung
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2025
reviews.body: I'm going to be honest before I continue with my review, and that is for the past four or so years, I have been more of a Samsung fanboy than an Apple fanboy. Ever since the iPhone X, Apple has been resting on its laurels for far too long, and the final straw was the hideous iPhone 14. People can be subjective about Jony Ive and his role in all the aesthetics of Apple products, but I bet even he had to let out a groan when all Apple did with the iPhone 14 was to make its already hideous camera lens array was to make it even more bigger and hideous. I must admit, Apple's nectar must be so sweet that every year they can wrap some poo up in tin foil and call it art, but anyone who has ever studied art, or even just love the art of aesthetics, can agree that there must be some sort of symmetry in design. If you are going to have a square lens array, at least put it in the middle of the top, so people can give you the golf clap that at least you tried. iPhone 11, 12, 13 already had bad design language, but to kick people in the nards with the 14 was the final middle finger for me: Apple stopped caring, Apple stopped trying. That thing, along with the 15 and 16, are FUGLY. At least with the regular 16, they had the decency to turn it into a pill-shaped array, but the last time Apple succeeded in its design language was all the way back with the iPhone X (and the subsequent XS).Thanks for listening to my Ted Talk, now let me tell you why I appreciate Samsung. The bottom line is, at least they try, and they are not afraid of trying. You have the main premium lineup in the S series (I use the S24 Ultra), and they have their experimental/progressive lineups in the Fold and Slip series. But they don't forget their backbone consumers (yes, the world exists outside of the US), and that's why they have their A series and M series. I think this particular A series is their cheapest iteration, at $200. And to be frank, there are better $200 phones out there, such as from Blu, and a generic company called Nuu, which makes pretty darn good phones with OLED screens and better specs.However, in the end, if you're not so sure about generic brands, then there's no other brand that I would recommend than Samsung for low to mid tier phones, as with everything, it comes down to support, both software wise, and in customer support if something goes wrong. From the software side, here it is in Samsung's own words:"SIX YEARS OF UPDATES. AWESOME SECURITY: Six years of OS and security updates mean you can keep your Galaxy A16 5G longer, making it a great value for years to come."Six years of software support is pretty awesome for any phone, but it's even more awesome for a $200 phone. That means for people without the means, that is a silent affirmation from Samsung that the phone should last at least that long. However, in this day and age, it's hard to recommend an Android phone with 4GB of RAM, because RAM is not just for running apps, but also the background processes those apps need to run, such as using your GPS, Wi-fi, Bluetooth, etc. Therefore, I would only recommend 20 or so apps with this phone (in addition to the ones it already comes with), whichever are the most necessary apps that you use everyday. Otherwise, it might slow down to a crawl if you fill this phone up with all the apps of your main phone. Otherwise, use one app at a time, and make sure to exit the ones you are not using. What is great, though is the AMOLED screen that Samsung has included, as usually this tech is reserved for their more premium phones. It's 90Hz, so it's pretty spry when you're scrolling, and the image quality is excellent. It's a pleasure to watch movies on this thing, very similar to my Flip 5.Since I am used to using Galaxy-level phones, it's a bit hard to go back down to the more entry-level phone. That's why for me, as a power user, I give this phone a four-star rating. However, if you are more utilitarian and practical, and don't need all the bells and whistles, than this phone can be your main daily driver. As for me, it makes an excellent secondary phone for when I travel internationally, as it's always good to have an emergency phone just in case, and it's especially effective for peace of mind. Overall, a good phone, and a much better value for its price.

reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great phone for the money
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2025
reviews.body: This Samsung Galaxy A16 5G is a great budget-friendly smartphone. For its price, it offers solid performance, a good display, and long battery life. The 5G connectivity is a nice bonus, making browsing and streaming smooth. The camera is decent for everyday use, and the build quality feels sturdy. The design is also sleek and good looking. This phone definitely delivers excellent value for the money.

reviews.title:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Nice basic android phone
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2025
reviews.body: One of the best qualities about this phone is the case. It's very sleek and a nice size overall. The cameras work well and provide very nice images. The interface of this phone is a very laggy but works for basic functions. You will have to play around with the settings to set things the way you may like them. If the processor was faster and didn't lag so much I would give the phone an additional star.

reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    This phone is AWESOME!
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2025
reviews.body: I was hesitant in trying this phone as I'd have to do the whole swapping the phone deal and adding it to Carrier service BUT....I'm so glad I did. This phone does not disappoint. It functions properly and as it should with an exceptional battery life. I love the size and it's easy to store and access when needed. The speed of this phone out preformed the other. Camera quality is a plus! I love in a rural area where service is not all that great. Never have I found a phone that had enough bars to pickup a phone call and actually let me have a full conversation in years...until now! The phone was unlocked and ready for use. I simply added my sim card to the phone and followed the instructions for setup through the phone and with service provider. Not very teck savvy either and was able to complete the whole process and navigate the phone easily. I would highly recommend over and over!

reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Good price for an unlocked phone
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2025
reviews.body: This phone is an unlocked phone so it can be used with whatever carrier you want, we have Cricket and it works with it. I think the price is very reasonable for an unlocked phone. This phone is about the same size as all of the rest of our phones, which honestly I would really like something smaller, but everything seems to be around the same size. This phone is actually lighter than our Moto phones. My daughters friends say that they can hear her better, but there is no headphone jack. I read that she can get an adapter for that, so we ordered one of those, so we'll see how that works. It has plenty of storage, and the touch screen and fingerprint sensor all seems to work really well. You do have to have a Samsung account, so that was something new that we never have had before. It takes very clear photos. It has fast charge, doesn't have wireless charging. I would compare it to my Moto stylus, but without a stylus, a few things are different, but seems to work just as well. I think it has a glass back, at least that is what it looks like to me.

reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Functions as expected for the upper bottom-end price.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2025
reviews.body: Switch-over was as easy as taking out old SIM card and installing it into the A16.  T-mobile is behaving as it was prior to the switch.  I elected not to use a transfer app, so it took longer to setup and configure.  The speed, the performance, and the function it has, is right about what I thought it'd be.There are 2 things I miss having with the A16 - 1 is the lack of a 3.5mm audio port (gotta use BT earbuds now).  2 is the Android v14 on it doesn't have the mobile data speed option - shows the speeds of data transfer happening.  But life will continue without these features...So overall, I give it a 4.8 star rating at this point (miss those 2 features I mentioned).  I'll return to update with any pros/cons that reveal themselves.

reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Capable entry level phone
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2025
reviews.body: There's a lot of like about this entry level phone - Be it the crisp 6.7" Super AMOLED screen or the 50MP wide angle, 5MP ultrawide and 2MP macro camera modules. This phone comes with Android 14 installed, and a promised 6 future major upgrades.However, with entry level pricing there won't be flagship specs all around. For example, that S AMOLED screen is 90Hz, as compared to other A series (A25/35) that are 120Hz. The WiFi is limited to ac.. no WiFi6/6e/7. The dust and water resistance rating limited to IP54. The cameras are limited to recording at 1080p 30fps. No wireless charging, wired charging is limited to 25W. USB while Type-C, is limited to 2.0. The chipset is Exynos, not Snapdragon.That said, these are still respectable specs, and you get a lot of value for your $200. In fact, as of this writing, there's also a gift card promotion being offered.

reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    A great mid-range phone with a budget price tag!
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2025
reviews.body: Other reviews have commented on it being "plasticy" - I say this - who carries around their phone without a case? Who cares what the outside is made of when if you're able to see it, it's destroyed the first time you drop it or the cat knocks it off the table?Activated on AT&T as simply as inserting my old SIM card and turning on the phone - zero issues!Performance is suprisingly good as is the display, being of the Super AMOLED variety. Colors are vibrant but not over-saturated as AMOLED tends to be.Battery life for me was one full day plus several hours the next day - enough to get to a charger should I forget to put it on the cord before going to bed.Volume from the speaker could stand to be a little louder but nothing to really complain about.6 major OS update - WOW - even my previous phone (Phone 7 pro) didn't offer that!This should be the new defacto-standard for inexpensive phones - way to go Samsung!

reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great phone for my needs!
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2025
reviews.body: I have no issues with this phone whatsoever. It was extremely simple to tranfer my contacts and apps from my old phone using smart switch. I'm pretty low tech, so that's really saying something! It's plenty fast for me. I haven't noticed anything that annoys me as of yet. I just transferred my SIM card from my old AT&T phone to this one and I was up and running immediately. I love the large screen. It's clear and bright. Cameras are good. I haven't tried all the features yet, but I'm very happy so far. Phones are crazy expensive, so I'm impressed by the low price on this one. It feels good and sounds decent as well. I have no problem recommending this phone to average users such as myself.

reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    A Worthwhile Upgrade
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2025
reviews.body: Moving from the Samsung A10 to this was a big improvement. The AMOLED display is brighter and sharper, making videos and browsing way more enjoyable. It’s faster too—apps open quickly, and there’s no lag when switching between tasks.I also love the expandable storage, which means no more constantly deleting stuff. The fast charging is a huge step up from the A10, saving me a lot of time. It feels sturdy but still lightweight, and the blue-black color is a nice touch.If you’re upgrading from an older model, this phone is a solid choice. It’s worth it for the display, speed, and overall performance.

reviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Slower than IE
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2025
reviews.body: I've had this phone for 10 months, it's slow. It responds slowly to touch. Apps of varying size and usage run laggy and crash frequently. It's noticeably slow. It has trouble running more than one app at a time. If I need information from another app, and try to toggle to my previous app, it will already have been closed in the background and will start over from the beginning. I have to have a pen and paper to take notes while filling out forms on my phone, my first android phone wasn't this bad. When I play music on a streaming app, it stops randomly of its own volition. Restarting helps for a short time. I've deleted apps down to the barest bones, moved my photos off local storage, even reset a few times. Happens on wifi and all levels of signal strength from a large national carrier. I'm an IT professional, I've pulled out all the stops, this phone is just slow. I will not miss it come upgrade time. I would not recommend this phone.

If you try to Google something while watching YouTube in the floating square, the video stutters. You can't change apps without significant lag. Reminds me of dial up internet. It's so bad I'm using my old phone. Also, in an emergency, getting to the phone app wouldn't be very fast. Basically you can't rely on this phone in an emergency if you need to dial 911 fast. Shame on you samsung for putting your name on this phone.

reviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    The "Just Right" Phone
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2025
reviews.body: The Samsung Galaxy A16 5G will probably be the best-selling individual phone model in the world for 2025. It sells well because it meets all the needs of the average person at a very reasonable price. This model, the SM-A166U (US version) has a nice OLED full HD screen, a 90Hz refresh rate, 4GB of RAM and 128 GB of storage, as well as a micro SD slot for additional storage. It does not have a headphone jack, which for 2025, has been deleted. Calls are nice and clear and it will receive 6 Android OS updates and 7 years of security updates - a nice addition by Samsung.  It should work with all of the major US carriers as well as the numerous MVNOs being the US model. This phone has been on sale since October in other areas of the world but has only gone on sale in the US since January 9th 2025. My only complaint about this phone is that it is only sold as a 4GB 128GB version in the US, whereas other parts of the world can get versions that have up to 8 GB of RAM and 256 GB of storage. Amazon sells these variants at a slightly higher price. If you're a T-Mobile, Metro or Mint Mobile customer, you might be able to use these GSM variants and have a better, faster and more future-proof phone. Check what 5G and 4G bands your carrier uses to be sure your A16 5G will work. The only downside is these variants don't come with a warranty. If you're a Verizon customer, stick with the US model.
